framework_intro.para:
Here is a framework to help you present data effectively using a line graph. This framework first gives statements summarizing what the line graph is going to be about; then commentary based on the line graph; and, finally, the line graph itself with a title.
There are spaces for you to add your own text and graph.

step.label: How can data be presented effectively?

commentary.para: One of the main ways you can present your data effectively is to use visuals. Visuals summarize your data and make it easy for readers to understand what has been found in your research.
This framework shows you how to use line graphs effectively.

step.label: Why has the writer used line graphs?

commentary.para: This is an extract from the ‘International Journal of Epidemiology’. It looks at social disparities in BMI trajectories and uses a line graph to convey findings. Line graphs are used when you need to show how one or more variables vary and they are particularly useful for noting trends.
Here is the framework that was used to present these data.
The purpose of the statements is to show what the line graph in this section is going to be about.
The purpose of the commentary is to interpret the findings for the reader by:
pointing out what the reader should notice from the visual
drawing a conclusion from the visual
Line graphs are used when you need to show how one or more variables vary and they are particularly useful for noting trends.
The graph should have a suitable title.
Use numbers or ordering to list findings.
Words and phrases that highlight trends.

checklist.point: You must know and understand your data well and then use visuals carefully to ensure that they efficiently display your data in a meaningful way.
There are many different visuals you can choose from to present your data. Two options are: tables and bar charts. Other common forms of visual are line graphs and pie charts.
All visuals need to be accompanied by two elements. These are: </br>1. Statements that summarize what your visual is about. </br>2. A commentary that interprets your findings for the reader.
Organize your data and comments into the framework.
Have I used a title for my line graph?
Have I summarized what the line graph is about?
Have I interpreted the findings for the reader?
Have I used numbers or ordering to list findings?
Have I used words and phrases to highlight trends?
Have I used the passive to report the findings?
Have I quoted and referenced my sources accurately?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar, spelling and punctuation?

paragraph.name: Commentary on the line graph
paragraph.tip: TIP The commentary on your findings will include some discussion of the significance of your findings. This should not be confused with your discussion section. The commentary on the findings only interprets the data for your reader. In your discussion section, you will widen the discussion by linking it to literature on the topic and discussing the implications of your findings.

content.para:
Members of the earliest cohort (born in 1958) were high-school seniors in 1976. Although height and weight data are not available for this cohort until the age of 28 (in 1986),the BMI trajectory for this group exhibits a gradual increase over adulthood. However, for each successive cohort, BMI scores are higher and the early adult BMI trajectory becomes increasingly steep.As a result, successive cohorts become ‘overweight’ (BMI>25) at increasingly earlier points in the life course.
(Clarke P., O'Malley P. M., Johnston L. D. and Schulenberg J. E., 2009) For the full reference, see References.
